sect2.title: Displaying the Help Pages
sect2.para: When working with the &dbpi; web interface, you can display the user guide as context-sensitive web help in a separate tab at any time. Proceed as follows to display the Help contents:

step.para:
In the navigation bar of the web interface or the respective view on the right side, click Help Button
(Display Help Pages).

result.para: The Help is opened in a separate browser tab.

note.para: If you are in a view, the help contents for the active view are displayed by default.

searchin web helpUse the text field Search to search for a string within the web help contents. To do this, enter the desired search string in the search field and select the desired entry from the list of search hits to switch to the corresponding text section.

sect2.title: Displaying System Information
sect2.para: When working with the &dbpi; web interface, you can display information about the client and server software in a separate dialog. Proceed as follows to display the system information:

step.para:
In the navigation bar, of the web interface on the right side click System information button
(system information).

result.para: The System Information dialog opens. The information in the System Information dialog is divided into the following three sections:

sect2.title: Modifying System Settings
sect2.para: When working with the &dbpi; web interface, you can configure system settings such as the log level, automatic detection of the REST API version, path to the &dbpi; server, etc. The following sections describe which system settings you can modify and which settings are supported in each case.

sect3.title: Configuring the DocBridge Pilot Log Level
sect3.para: By default, the log messages for &dbpi; are displayed for the log level Info and higher. You can set the log levels for &dbpi; and &dbmi; independently of each other (see ). Proceed as follows to change the log settings for &dbpi;:

step.para:
In the title bar, click the preferences icon user preferences icon
.

result.para: The available settings are displayed in a separate dialog.

step.para: In the Settings dialog, click the entry System on the left.

result.para: The available system settings are displayed.

step.para: In the DocBridge Pilot Log Level pane, select the desired log level for &dbpi;.
The following settings are currently available:
Click OK, to close the dialog and only display log messages for &dbpi; for the selected log level and higher.

result.para: The changes are applied without a restart.

sect3.title: Configuring the DocBridge Mill Log Level
sect3.para: By default, the log messages for &dbmi; are displayed for the log level Info and higher. You can set the log levels for &dbpi; and &dbmi; independently of each other (see ). Proceed as follows to change the log settings for &dbmi;:

step.para:
In the title bar, click the preferences icon user preferences icon
.

result.para: The available settings are displayed in a separate dialog.

step.para: In the Settings dialog, click the entry System on the left.

result.para: The available system settings are displayed.

step.para: In the DocBridge Mill Log Level pane, select the desired log level for &dbpi;.
The following settings are currently available:
Click OK, to close the dialog and only display log messages for &dbpi; for the selected log level and higher.

result.para: The changes are applied without a restart.

sect3.title: Configuring the Automatic Detection of the REST API Version
sect3.para: By default the &dbpi; Web interface will automatically check which version of the &dbpi; REST API is installed. The thus detected version is displayed, for example, in the System Settings dialog (for more information, see ). You can disable this automatic detection of the REST API version and select the desired version manually. This is useful, for example, if you have multiple versions installed in parallel and want to deliberately switch from one version to another. Proceed as follows to change the mode for auto-detecting the REST API version for &dbpi;:

step.para:
In the title bar, click the preferences icon user preferences icon
.

result.para: The available settings are displayed in a separate dialog.

step.para: In the Settings dialog, click the entry System on the left.

result.para: The available system settings are displayed.

step.para: In the Automatic Detection of REST API Version pane, select the desired mode.
The following settings are currently available:

listitem.para: With this setting, the currently used/installed version of the &dbpi; REST API is automatically detected. If you have several versions installed in parallel, the latest version will be used by default.
With this setting, the detected versions are available for selection in a separate section and you can select the desired version of the &dbpi; REST API manually.

step.para: If you selected the option Disable, select the desired version of the REST interface in the DocBridge Pilot REST API Version pane.
Click OK, to close the dialog and use the REST API in the selected version.

result.para: The changes are applied without a restart.

sect2.title: Changing the Authentication Method
sect2.para: The &dbpi; web interface uses the Basic Authentication authentication method by default for communication with the &dbpi; server and other components. However, if you have installed advanced authentication modules, you can also enable authentication with the Compart module &ana; or JWT authentication.
Proceed as follows to change the authentication method:

step.para:
In the title bar, click the preferences icon user preferences icon
.

result.para: The available settings are displayed in a separate dialog.

step.para: In the Settings dialog, click the entry Authentication on the left.

result.para: The available authentication methods are displayed.

step.para: In the Authentication Method pane, select the desired setting.
The following settings are currently available:

listitem.para: With the default setting, you use the preconfigured authentication settings for the communication between &dbpi; and the &dbpi; web interface.

With this setting, you can use an existing &ana; server for authentication. The specified server must be installed and already running. If you select the A&A Authentication Server option, additional configuration panes are displayed, where you can configure the settings for communication with &ana;.

step.para: If you selected the option A&A Authentication Server, specify the URL to the running instance of &ana; in the Authentication Server URL pane. With the specified default value, the authentication server is expected to be on the local system (where the &dbpi; web interface is installed). If &ana; is installed on another system, you can enter a full URL (including port specification).
If you selected the A&A Authentication Server option, specify the ID to be sent to the A&A authentication server in the Client ID pane.
Click OK to close the dialog and apply the selected authentication method.

result.para: The changes are applied without restart.

sect2.title: Creating a Desktop
sect2.para: When you open the &dbpi; web interface for the first time, only the navigation bar is initially visible. Before you can select and display views, you must first create a desktop. A desktop acts as a container for any number of views. You can use the desktop to group frequently used views. You can create multiple desktops to switch between different combinations of views (or individual views). Proceed as follows to create and configure a new desktop and assign it views.

step.para:
On the left side of the navigation bar, click Create Desktop Button
(Create Desktop).

result.para: The new desktop is created with the default name Desktop 1 (for information on changing the default name, see ). The side bar with the icons for the available views is displayed. The icon for deleting the existing desktop is displayed in the navigation bar.

step.para: Add more views as required.

sect2.title: Renaming a Desktop
sect2.para: desktopmodify nameYou can change the default desktop name any time. Proceed as follows to rename a desktop.

step.para: In the navigation bar, double-click on the desktop name.

result.para: The desktop name switches to editing mode.

step.para: Enter the desired new name in the text field.

note.para: Note that, in addition to characters and numbers, umlauts and special characters are also supported within the desktop name.

step.para: Press the Enter key or click outside the text field.

result.para: The changed name is saved automatically. The desktop name leaves the editing mode.

sect2.title: Arranging Widgets
sect2.para: desktoparranging widgetsIf you have multiple widgets open on the desktop, overlapping windows can quickly make working in the widgets confusing. Therefore, the opened widgets are, by default, arranged automatically. If you open more widgets, the existing widgets and the new widgets are rearranged.
If you prefer to arrange the widgets manually, you have the option to disable the auto-arrange functionality. Proceed as follows to switch from automatic to manual widget placement.

step.para:
In the title bar, click the preferences icon user preferences icon
.

result.para: The available settings are displayed in a separate dialog.

step.para: In the Widget Placement pane, select the desired setting.
The following settings are currently available:

listitem.para: With this setting, the open widgets are automatically arranged based on a grid layout, if you open a new widget or close an existing widget, the widgets are rearranged.

note.para: With this setting, you do not have the option to manually adjust the size or position of a widget. However, you can maximize individual widgets (enlarge them to page size).

listitem.para: With this setting the individual widgets in the desktop are opened as overlapping windows and you can freely choose the size and position of the individual windows. If you open a new widget or close an existing widget, the size and position of the other widgets are not affected.

sect2.title: Closing all Widgets
sect2.para: desktopclose viewsIf you have multiple views open in the desktop, you can close all open views in one step.

step.para: Make sure that you have selected the desired desktop.

In the navigation bar of the web interface, click Close all Widgets button
.

result.para: The Close All Widgets dialog opens.

step.para: Click Confirm to close all opened views.
Click Cancel to not close the opened views.

result.para: The Close All Widgets dialog closes. All previously opened views are closed. The selected desktop is empty.

sect2.title: Toggling Full Screen Mode
sect2.para: full screenenabling/disablingWhen working in the &dbpi; web interface, you can toggle into or out of full-screen mode at any time. After logging in, the button for toggling the display mode is available at any time, regardless of the selected views or desktops. By default the &dbpi; web interface is not displayed in full-screen mode. Proceed as follows to change the display mode.

step.para: In the navigation bar of the web interface, click Button full-screen mode

result.para:
The web interface is displayed in full screen mode. The button changes from Full screen mode button
to Normal screen mode button
.

step.para:
Click Normal screen mode button
to exit the full-screen mode.

sect2.title: Deleting a Desktop
sect2.para: You can delete an existing desktop at any time. Proceed as follows to delete a desktop.

step.para: Select the desired desktop by clicking the desktop name in the overview table.

result.para: The views related to the selected desktop are displayed in the workspace of the web interface.

step.para:
On the left side of the navigation bar, click Delete Desktop Button
(Delete Desktop).

result.para: The desktop is deleted. If the deleted desktop was the only desktop, you will have to create a new desktop before you can display views again (for more information, see ). In this case, the sidebar and the icon for deleting desktops are no longer displayed. If there is at least one more desktop, the view automatically switches to the next desktop.

sect1.title: Configuring User Settings for the Web Interface

sect2.title: Restoring Default Settings
sect2.para: You have the option to reset all settings which are available in the Settings dialog, to the default settings. When you restore the default settings, the following settings are reset to the specified default values:

row.entry: Automatic detection of REST API version

sect2.para: Proceed as follows to restore the default settings.

step.para:
In the title bar, click the preferences icon user preferences icon
.

result.para: The available settings are displayed in a separate dialog.

step.para: In the Settings dialog, click the entry Reset Settings on the left.

result.para: The Reset Settings pane is displayed.

step.para: In the Reset Settings section, tick the checkbox to restore the default settings for all settings in the Settings dialog.
Click Confirm to close the dialog and reset all settings in the Settings dialog to the default settings.

result.para: The changes are applied without restart.

sect1.title: Configuring User Settings for a View
sect1.para: Regardless of the specific view you are in, you can configure settings for the view.

sect1.title: Selecting Table Entries
sect1.para: The central element in all views is the overview table with the individual entries of the respective type. The following descriptions therefore apply to all views and overview tables.

If the overview table contains at least one entry, you can select an entry (or multiple entries) from the overview table. To do this, simply place the cursor in the desired table row. If you have selected an entry, the properties of the selected entry are displayed in the details pane on the right.

note.para: If you have selected multiple entries, the properties of the last selected entry are displayed in the details pane.

sect1.para: Each overview table contains an additional checkbox in the title bar, with which you can select or deselect all available entries in the table. If you have selected at least one entry in the table, the checkbox in the title bar contains a rectangle. This way you can see if (at least) one entry is still selected, even for large tables.

note.para: When you have selected all entries in the table, you can click on individual entries to deselect them.

sect1.title: Configuring the Pagination for Table Entries
sect1.para: The central element in all views is the overview table with the individual entries. By default, 100 entries are displayed on each table page. If the overview table contains more than 100 entries, multiple pages are created automatically. In this case, you can navigate between the pages using the pagination buttons or go to a specific page using the text field. The following descriptions apply to all views and overview tables.

If the overview table contains more than the selected number of elements per page (50 elements by default), the navigation elements are displayed at the bottom of the page below the table. Proceed as follows to to navigate between pages and go to a specific page.

step.para: Open a widget with multiple elements (for our example we will use the Processes widget) in the desktop.

result.para: The widget opens in the workspace. The overview table contains the first page of entries. At the bottom of the page (below the overview table) the navigation buttons are displayed.

step.para:
Below the overview table, click Icon for navigation to the next page
(Next page).

result.para: In the overview table, the second page of entries is displayed. Below the overview table, Page 2 is displayed as the current page. The navigation button for returning to the previous page is available.

step.para:
Below the overview table, click Icon for navigation to the previous page
(Previous page).

result.para: In the overview table, the first page of entries is displayed. Below the overview table, Page 1 is displayed as the current page. Only the navigation button for going to the next page is available.

sect1.title: Managing Predefined Roles
sect1.para: After installation, &dbpi; provides some preconfigured user roles. You can assign these user roles to existing users or groups in your LDAP/AD system as required.
